ArticleInfo.ArticleTitle: Metamaterial patch antenna radiation pattern agility

Abstract.Heading: Abstract
Abstract.Para: In this paper we address the introduction of antenna’s radiation pattern agility using an agile metamaterial. We design an agile metamaterial having two different behaviors which can be controlled by an external command. This agile metamaterial is used to design an agile lens which comprises two grids each composed of two regions: the first one constitutes a focusing zone (FZ) and the second one the lens body. The focusing zone parameters—refraction index, size, shape and position in the grid—can be modified using an external switching system (OFF or ON stat); by modifying the FZ parameters one can control the patch antenna’s radiation-pattern main-lobe beamwidth and direction (pointing angle) in E- and H-planes.

Section1.Heading: Introduction
Section1.Para: Among the most important metamaterial applications in the antenna field we can mention the antenna performance enhancement and size reduction [1–3]. However, control of antenna characteristics remains a major challenge of metamaterial use in the antenna domain. The goal is to design agile antennas [4, 5], the characteristics of which it is possible to change using an external control system. This makes telecommunication systems more flexible. Generally, in this kind of structures Ferroelectric films [6] or switching elements (diodes, MEMs, etc.) are used to ensure their agility [7, 8]. Agile antennas can be classified into two categories: (i) frequency agile antennas, for which we can modify their operating frequency, and (ii) radiation pattern agile antennas, for which we can change their radiation pattern characteristics (pointing direction, main lobe beamwidth, etc.). These antennas can be used for telecommunication applications, metrology (detection angles of arrival) and also for RADAR applications [9].

In this study, we are interested in antenna’s radiation pattern agility. The aim is to steer the radiation pattern using a lens based on an agile metamaterial (programmable). Note that the use of a metamaterial-based lens above a patch antenna improves considerably the antenna directivity (16 dB instead of 7 dB for the antenna alone) [9, 10].

Section1.Heading: Agile metamaterial design
Section1.Para:
The elementary cell of our agile metamaterial is sketched in Fig. 1. It is made of disconnected cross-like conducting strips, printed on a dielectric substrate. The disconnected branches of the cross can be joined with switching devices such as diodes, MEMs, etc. According to switch states (ON or OFF), the unit cell has two different commutable behaviors. The first one corresponds to the disconnected cross type (switch OFF) and behaves like an effective medium with a refraction index n 1 higher than unity. The second one corresponds to the connected cross type (switch ON) and has a positive and close to zero refraction index n 2. The actionable behavior of our unit cell allows us introducing the metamaterial agility.
Fig. 1
Agile metamaterial elementary cell disconnected (a) and connected cross (b)

The agile metamaterial elementary motifs are printed on a dielectric substrate of permittivity ε
r =2.2 and thickness h=0.8 mm [10]. The operating frequency is 40 GHz, hence the corresponding wavelength in free space is 8 mm. Accordingly, the greatest dimension of the metamaterial unit cell must be much lower than the operating wavelength, to respect the homogenization conditions [11]. So, we fixed it at a=2 mm (lower than λ/3≈2.66 mm).

The conducting strip width w, the gap size g (Fig. 1b), and many other factors, such as the metallization thickness t, the substrate permittivity ε
r and thickness h, directly govern the agile metamaterial electromagnetic properties. Since we have fixed some of them (t, ε
r and h), we use w and g as design parameters to tune the agile metamaterial unit cell behaviors (corresponding to connected and disconnected motifs).

A parametric study is used to obtain the dimensions of the agile metamaterial unit cell. We obtain the constitutive parameters (ε reff and μ reff) and the refraction index of the agile metamaterial with the Fresnel inversion method using the S parameters of the unit cell, obtained by a finite difference based commercial simulation code.

Section1.Heading: Agile metamaterial characterization
Section1.Para:
Figure 2 shows that the connected cross-based metamaterial exhibits a plasmonic-type permittivity frequency function. For frequencies larger than the plasma frequency the relative permittivity stays between 0 and 1. It can be seen also that for w=0.25 mm or w=0.3 mm, the metamaterial presents a plasma frequency equal or a little less than 40 GHz and a very low real part (close to zero) in the operating frequency range (40–45 GHz) which correspond to the desired profile. So we can fix the conductor width at w=0.25 mm.
Fig. 2
Effective permittivity of the connected cross type metamaterial for different values of w. (a) Real part; (b) Imaginary part

The connected cross type metamaterial permeability is represented in Fig. 3, for different values of w.
Fig. 3
Effective permeability of the connected cross type metamaterial for different values of w. (a) Real part; (b) Imaginary part

Once the effective permittivity profile for the connected cross type metamaterial is attained, the w parameter is fixed. Now, all the connected cross dimensions are known (ε
r , h, a, and w) as are even those of the disconnected cross unit cell. The gap g remains to be determined. To do this, g is varied, in the simulation, to obtain the desired effective permeability and refraction index profiles. The effective permeability must present a profile close to unity and the refraction index should present a profile as flat as possible corresponding to a low dispersive behavior.

Figures 4, 5 and 6, present the constitutive parameters and the refraction index of the connected (g=0 mm) and disconnected (g≠0 mm) cross-based metamaterial. From Fig. 4 one sees that the constitutive parameters (ε reff and μ reff) have positive imaginary parts which account for losses in the effective medium. It can be seen also that the imaginary part of the permittivity is rather small (less than 0.3) for the connected cross type metamaterial compared with that of the disconnected cross type. This attests to the low-loss nature of the connected cross type metamaterial. From Fig. 5 it can be seen that the real part of the effective permeability of the connected cross type metamaterial is much greater than unity and that of the disconnected cross type. This is due to the closed metallic loops formed by the connected crosses (current loops sources) which leads to stronger magnetic activity.
Fig. 4
Effective permittivity of disconnected (g≠0) and connected (g=0) cross type metamaterial for different values of g, with w=0.15 mm. (a) Real part; (b) Imaginary part
Fig. 5
Effective permeability of disconnected (g≠0) and connected (g=0) cross type metamaterial for different values of g, with w=0.15 mm. (a) Real part; (b) Imaginary part
Fig. 6
Effective refraction index of disconnected (g≠0) and connected (g=0) cross type metamaterial for different values of g, with w=0.15 mm

We opt for the gap value g according to the desired electromagnetic properties for the agile metamaterial. Mainly, these are: (i) for the connected cross-based metamaterial, a plasma frequency equal or little less than 40 GHz, and refraction index close to zero, and (ii) for the disconnected cross type, a real part curve of the permeability as close as possible to unity, a real part curves as flat as possible for the permittivity and the refraction index. As we can clearly seen from Figs. 4, 5 and 6, the desired behavior of the agile metamaterial corresponds to g=0.15 mm.

Section1.Heading: Antenna’s radiation pattern agility
Section1.Para:
We use the agile metamaterial to design an agile (actionable) metamaterial lens composed of two gratings that can be externally reconfigured. Each of them is made up of two regions (Fig. 7), the first one forming a focusing zone (FZ) and the second one, the lens body (host medium). The refraction index, the size, shape and position of the FZ can be programmed by acting on the switching devices (state ON or OFF). This agile metamaterial lens is used to control in an active manner the emission from an antenna. Our designed Agile Radiation Pattern Antenna (ARPA) is depicted in Fig. 8. The structure is formed by a patch antenna on which the agile metamaterial lens is superposed. Modifying the FZ parameters (size, shape, position, and refraction index) allows to control the antenna’s radiation pattern properties: main lobe direction (pointing angle) and beamwidth in both E- and H-planes. Figure 6 shows the used metamaterial refraction indices profiles corresponding to the connected and disconnected cross type. The refraction index contrast (mean value) is about Δn=1.01. The used agile metamaterial unit cell dimensions (Fig. 1) are: cell period a=2 mm, cross width w=0.15 mm, cross length L=0.675 mm, gap g=0.25 mm and a metallization thickness t=0.035 mm.
Fig. 7
Agile lens gating: host medium with refraction index n 2 and FZ with index n 1
Fig. 8
Agile radiation pattern structure

The simulations show that the ARPA directivity is maximum when the host medium of the first grid and the focusing zone of the second grid of the agile lens are based on a connected cross type metamaterial and the host medium of the second grid and the focusing zone of the first grid are based on a disconnected cross type metamaterial.

Section1.Para:

However, the focusing zone acts only on the H-plane of the radiation pattern when it is placed between positions P3 and P4 (Fig. 9). The FZ positioned in P3 rotates the main beam pattern by 11.8° and by 36° if it is positioned in P4. Normally, the main lobe rotation angle corresponding to position P4 should be negative. However, due to the undesirable radiation from the antenna feed line which perturbs drastically the radiation pattern, it makes difficult to determine the radiation-pattern main-lobe pointing angle. In Fig. 10 it seems that the radiation pattern corresponding to position P3 can be obtained by a rotation clockwise of that corresponding of position P4. We note that the amplitude of main lobe pointing rotation angle is about 8° in the E-plane. This is not sufficient for the radiation pattern steering. This can be explained by the weak contrast Δn between the refraction index of the behaviors of the agile metamaterials used to design the agile lens (the host medium and the focusing zone).
Fig. 10
Radiation pattern steering of the ARPA by positioning the FZ

From the previous results we expect that agile metamaterial lens steering performances can be improved by: (i) increasing the refraction index contrast between the two behaviors of the agile metamaterial, and (ii) the alignment of the centers of the focusing zones with the patch antenna center. Both effects will be detailed in the following sections.

Section2.Heading: Effect of the material refraction index contrast
Section2.Para:
To improve steering performance of the agile metamaterial lens, we increase the refraction index contrast between the two metamaterials used to realize the host medium and the FZ. To do this we change the unit cell parameters to lower the connected cross type metamaterial refraction index n 1 (mean value in the frequency range 40–45 GHz) and increase n 2 that of the disconnected cross type metamaterial. Figure 11 shows the new profiles of both refraction indices (n 1 and n 2). The mean value of the refraction index contrast is now equal to Δn=1.18 instead of Δn=1.01 for the previous lens used in Sect. 3.
Fig. 11
New agile lens refraction indices (Δn=1.18)
The new agile metamaterial unit cell dimensions (Fig. 1) are: cell period a=2 mm, cross width w=0.25 mm, cross length L=0.725 mm, gap g=0.15 mm and a metallization thickness t=0.035 mm.

Table 2 and Fig. 12 show that the amplitude of the rotation angle of radiation pattern main lobe is 15° in the E-plane (positions P1 and P2). We observe an improvement of about 6.8° compared to that obtained by the low contrast refraction index lens. In the H-plane, for the same reasons mentioned above, the rotation angle amplitude is difficult to determine. It can be estimated at −2.3° clockwise and 8.7° counterclockwise (positions P3 and P4).

Section2.Heading: Effect of the focusing zones and patch antenna alignment
Section2.Para:
In addition to the refraction index contrast, the alignment of the focusing zones with the patch antenna is another parameter which can be used to improve the agile metamaterial lens radiation pattern steering capability. Indeed, the previous results are obtained with the two focusing zones disposed one on the other and were not aligned with the patch antenna as is depicted in Fig. 13a (not aligned FZs). To the positions 5 and 6 with not aligned focusing zones, let us relate the new positions 5n and 6n with both focusing zones aligned with the patch antenna. Figure 13b shows the new focusing zones placement configuration. The centers of the focusing zones are placed in the same direction as seen from the center of the patch (aligned FZs). We use in this case the metamaterial with Δn=1.18.
Fig. 13
View and side view of the ARPA: (a) with not aligned FZs, (b) with aligned FZs

Figure 14 shows a comparison of the antenna radiation patterns in E-plane corresponding to the aligned and not aligned positions 5n and 5, respectively 6n and 6 of the focusing zones. We observe clearly that the alignment of the focusing zones reduces the radiation main-lobe beamwidth and improves the antenna gain.
Fig. 14
Radiation pattern steering of the ARPA by positioning the aligned and not aligned FZ

Section1.Heading: Conclusion
Section1.Para: In this study, we highlight the possibility of introducing antenna radiation pattern agility by using an agile metamaterial lens. In the E-plane, the different results obtained show clearly the main-lobe radiation pattern steering, due to the FZ positioning. Whereas, in the H-plane, the presence of secondary side lobes degrades strongly the radiation pattern and the steering effect becomes less visible. The antenna gain and the amplitude of main-lobe pointing angle depend upon the alignment of the FZs and the refraction index contrast of the two materials used to realize the agile metamaterial lens (host medium and FZ).

We have introduced the metamaterial agility by designing an externally actionable elementary unit cell based on a disconnected cross shape equipped with MEMs switches. According to the state of the MEM switches (ON or OFF), the metamaterial refraction index flips between two values, n 1 close to zero and n 2 greater than the unity.
